questionListItems.title: How can I find help on using Office of the Public Guardian Online (OPGO)?

answer.body:
You may view instructional videos and Quick Reference Guides (QRGs) on how to use the various services on OPGO, such as applying for an LPA, accepting an LPA Donee appointment, certifying an LPA, and submitting a Deputy Report. The videos are subtitled and voiced in English, Mandarin, Malay and Tamil. The videos and QRGs are available in OPGO under ‘Resources’ tab at the top of the window. You can access OPGO at this following link: https://opg-eservice.msf.gov.sg.


If you need guided assistance using OPGO, you can seek help from your family first. Alternatively, you may also approach community touchpoints at the Citizen Connect Centres, located at selected Community Centres, as well as ServiceSG centres that can help those who need support for OPGO.

questionListItems.title: What is the new online Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) process in Office of the Public Guardian Online (OPGO)?

answer.body:
Step 1*: On OPGO, Donor completes LPA and system will route it to Donee(s).

Step 2: Donee(s) accepts appointment on OPGO.

Step 3: Upon all Donee(s) acceptance of appointment, Donor visits Certificate Issuer (CI)’s office for certification and signing of LPA.

Step 4: LPA is submitted by CI on OPGO. Step 5: All Donor and Donee(s) will receive e-notifications when the submitted LPA is accepted for registration and upon registration.


*This process is only for LPA Form 1. For LPA Form 2, a Donor starts by visiting a lawyer to draft the LPA in OPGO. Access OPGO and click the ‘Resources’ tab at the top of the screen to view our instructional videos and Quick Reference Guides (QRGs) on OPGO.

questionListItems.title: Does a Donor still need to visit a Certificate Issuer in person?

answer.body:
Yes, the Donor needs to visit a Certificate Issuer in-person to certify the LPA. 

This is to ensure that the Donor understands the purpose of the LPA and the scope of the authority conferred on Donee(s) as well as ensuring that there is no fraud or undue pressure used to induce the Donor to make the LPA.

questionListItems.title: How do I search for a certificate issuer?

answer.body:
Step 1: Login to OPGO

Step 2: Locate ‘Services’

Step 3: Click ‘Search for Certificate Issuer’

Step 4: Search for CI. You can filter your search by location, type of CI (doctor, lawyer or psychiatrist) and name of CI’s place of working.

questionListItems.title: Can I send my Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) to other individuals or third parties?

answer.body:
After an LPA is registered by OPG, the Donor and his/her Donees can view and send the LPA to individuals or third-party organizations via OPGO.


When sending to third parties, the LPA will be a password protected PDF document with an attachment. The process of viewing and sending the LPA is the same for the Donor and Donee but the Donee will only be able to send the LPA after declaring on OPGO that the Donor had been certified by a doctor to lack mental capacity.


You may refer to the OPGO Quick Reference Guides (QRGs) https://opg-eservice.msf.gov.sg/OPGO/QuickGuide_Reference.aspx for step-by-step guidance on how to send the LPA.

questionListItems.title: How will Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) support donors, donees and deputies who are less comfortable with technology?

answer.body: The LPA application in Office of the Public Guardian Online (OPGO), as well as instructional videos on the OPGO portal, is in English, Mandarin, Malay, and Tamil languages. Quick Reference Guides have also been developed for the various services in OPGO. Donors, Donees and Deputies may seek help from family members to assist them in accessing OPGO via Singpass, or approach community touchpoints at the Citizen Connect Centres and ServiceSG centres for support.

questionListItems.title: What are the safeguards as Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) digitalises its processes?

answer.body:
We have ensured that in our digital transformation journey, safeguards are kept in place for both LPA applications and Deputyship reporting:


  1. LPA certification by Certificate Issuers (CI) must meet the following requirements:

    • The CI must be a medical practitioner accredited by the Public Guardian, a practising lawyer, or a registered psychiatrist.

    • The CI must meet the donor in person to ensure that he/she understands the purpose of the LPA and its scope and is not induced by fraud or undue pressure to create the LPA.

    • To verify the donor’s identity, the CI must enter the donor’s NRIC number for OPGO to generate a one-time access code sent by SMS to the donor’s mobile number. The CI can only access the donor’s draft LPA after entering the correct access code, to proceed with certification.

  2. The donor must sign the LPA in the presence of the CI. Deputies and all parties to the LPA can only access OPGO via Singpass.

  3. OPGO sends instantaneous SMS and/or email notifications to all parties during various stages of the LPA application and Deputyship reporting. This allows all parties to be kept informed in real-time, so that they can alert OPG if there are any issues.

  4. OPGO is hosted on the Government Commercial Cloud with the appropriate cybersecurity measures.

questionListItems.title: How do I set up my National Digital Identity (NDI) and digitally sign the Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) with Singpass?

answer.body: You may refer to https://www.singpass.gov.sg/main/html/faq.html for a step-by-step guide on how to set up your NDI and digitally sign the LPAs with Singpass.

questionListItems.title: Can Donors make their Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) via My Legacy portal?

answer.body: Yes, you can refer to this link to make an LPA using My Legacy - https://mylegacy.life.gov.sg/find-a-service/lpa-acp/.

questionListItems.title: How to revoke my existing Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA)? My donee has passed on.

answer.body:
The steps to revoke an existing Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) are as follows:


  1. Complete and sign the revocation form: https://www.msf.gov.sg/docs/default-source/default-document-library/revocation_form.pdf

  2. Take reasonable steps to give written notice to other Donee(s) that you are revoking the LPA by delivering it personally, sending it via post, or if the postal address is not known, via email.

  3. Inform the Public Guardian of the revocation by providing the following items to the Office of the Public Guardian by post or email:

    • The completed and signed revocation form, and

    • A photocopy of your ID.

  4. Pay the cancellation fee of $30 via OPGO. OPG will provide instructions on how to make payment via email before processing your revocation.


If you are also making a new LPA application, please do so via the OPG Online system (OPGO).

 

The Public Guardian may also require the Donor to provide further information or documents before cancelling the registration of the LPA.

questionListItems.title: Is there a list showing the organizations in Singapore who can provide trusted professional Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) donees service?

answer.body: You can refer to MSF website https://www.msf.gov.sg/opg/Pages/About-PDD.aspx for more information

questionListItems.title: If I appoint Jointly Donees and one of my donee passed on, is remaining 1 donee the sole decision maker to act on the Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA)? (I do not have a replacement donee)

answer.body: If you appoint Jointly Donees, the Donees must act together and not individually. When any one Donee is no longer able to act, all the donees in the joint appointment will be terminated.

questionListItems.title: What if I do not have anyone suitable around me to be my Nominated Healthcare Spokesperson (NHS)?

answer.body: In the situation where there is no one suitable to be your spokesperson, you can also consider nominating a Professional Donee to represent your wishes for your ACP. You may find the full list of Professional Donees here: https://www.msf.gov.sg/what-we-do/opg/about-PDD-scheme.

questionListItems.title: How to get started on doing an Advance Care Planning (ACP) and how much does it cost?

answer.body:
You can begin with these simple steps:

  1. Reflect on what you want. Think about what is important and meaningful to you, the quality of life you want, and the medical treatment you are comfortable with.

  2. Choose your Nominated Healthcare Spokesperson(s) (NHS). Think about the people in your life you trust to convey your care preferences. Your NHS would ideally be someone who:

    • Knows you well. For example, a family member or a close friend.

    • Is willing to speak up for your goals and values on your behalf.

    • Can be trusted to act in your best interest and tell your doctors about the care you wish to receive when you lose mental capacity.

    • Be someone who can handle stressful situations well.

    • Is at least 21 years old, so that they can help make important decisions should the need arises. You may nominate up to two NHS. Both NHS should be aligned and in agreement about what your preferences are.

  3. Prepare a draft ACP form online on My Legacy (go.gov.sg/mylegacy-lpa-acp).

  4. Make an appointment with an ACP facilitator to discuss and submit your ACP to the National Electronic Healthcare Records (NEHR) system.


You may visit go.gov.sg/find-acp-facil for a list of ACP facilitators. Please check with the individual organisations on the cost. You can visit www.mylegacy.gov.sg for more details on how to start your ACP journey.

questionListItems.title: Is digital signature for Advance Care Planning (ACP) legally valid?

answer.body:
To do an Advance Care Plan (ACP), you need to speak with a certified ACP facilitator. This can be done either through an in-person ACP session or virtually via tele-conferencing. Depending on your preferred mode of facilitation, ACP providers do offer the option of digital signing on PDF documents upon completion of the ACP discussion. 
 
If you are attending a in-person ACP discussion session, the ACP provider would usually prepare the ACP discussion worksheet and form in the same session for you to vet through and give a wet-ink signature as acknowledgement of the discussion session. 

If your ACP discussion is conducted virtually, the ACP provider will then send the encrypted PDF versions of the ACP worksheet & form via email after the session, and you can then insert your digital signature. You may refer to the list of ACP providers who provide tele and physical ACP services from the ACP directory on My Legacy.
